In the heart of the City, in a quiet side street in the Rothschild banking district, Swithin's Italian restaurant is a very special place to dine and entertain. Beneath London's pavements lie the old vaults of Sandeman's, where port was bottled for hundreds of years. These arching cellars are the setting for Swithin's fine Italian dining room. The bricked vaults may have an air of rusticity, but the leather banquettes, gleaming silver and crystal, and white linens create an elegant space for enjoying first class cuisine. The menu includes classic dishes, many with an inventive modern twist. Try starter of fillet of beef carpaccio on mixed leaves with lemon vinaigrette, second course of home made spinach and ricotta ravioli -- all the pastas are home made, with chopped tomato, butter and sage, main course of calves liver and bacon with sauteed baby spinach and mash, or one of the Italian veal, or a fresh fish dish. There are superb vegetarian choices, too. The mostly-French wine list has a few well-chosen Italians and a tempting line in champagnes. Very professional service.

This restaurant has a small bar at the entrance and an elegant dining room in a classic-style distributed on various levels. Contemporary cuisine with an Italian base is served.


Like a more sedate version of The Poseidon Adventure, the interior of Al Fresco resembles that of an upturned ship, wooden hull arching overhead, while discreet tables stretch out either side of the narrow aisle.

The upshot is a rather atmospheric, intimate little Italian restaurant, with more than a few surprises. The menu is a study in satisfaction, with a few twists on some standard classics. The duck risotto is rich and gooey, the pizzas thin and crispy, and come with real prosciutto ham – not turkey ham, not beef ham, not fish ham, but delicious prosciutto.

The bread is also worth a mention, and it arrives in three different varieties (the olive bread is sensationalwith an irresistible tapenade for dipping. The overall effect is of a restaurant that knows what it’s doing.

The service is decent, although not afraid of interrupting you in order to wave the world’s most oversized pepper grinder over your meal. The desserts are also impressive, with a separate ice cream menu for those still not convinced, although you can’t go far wrong with the dolce goloso, a platter of classic, tiny Italian treats.

Al Fresco is undoubtedly a touch of class, and well worth going down with the ship for.

There’s nothing particularly innovative about Andiamo!, making its overly enthusiastic punctuation seem a little unnecessary. What it does is serve passable Italian fare at a reasonable price. To be fair, the restaurant, hidden behind the Grand Hyatt’s indoor jungle, has more than a few well-executed staples on its menu.

The beef carpaccio, which is tender and pinkly fresh, makes for a solid opener (best to skip the scallops here, which are killed with a tad too much time on the stove. Pastas can be a bit stodgy: gnocci proves chewy where it should be airy, and an order of carbonara comes in a creamy block.

Fish, however, comes out fresh and flavoursome (the cod is always a good bet). Desserts, while satisfying, can also be a bit run of the mill. The chocolate mousse is appropriately creamy and made with decent-quality cocoa; it may not redefine the medium, but it does hit the spot.

This nicely located, first-rate Italian is spread out over two floors. Downstairs there's a small bar for an aperitif or coffee. Starters such as grilled artichoke hearts and antipasto misto, familiar home-made pastas, daily fish specialities and meat dishes such as oxtail filled with truffles are among the reasons to linger upstairs. Service is attentive but not intrusive. The third of Piero de Vetis' restaurants (after Osteria No.1 and Sale e Tabacchi) and definitely the best.

Bice plays on the theme of an Italian restaurant in an international setting, from, ‘Buona seras’ uttered by Asian waiting staff, to set-pieces such as giant pepper mills and trolley loads of olive oil.

Any suspicions about the speedy appearance of dishes are soon allayed; lobster carpaccio with caviar and artichoke heart – one of the signature dishes – makes a wonderful starter, and the pasta dishes are inventive too – try the black and white tagliolini with tiger prawns, asparagus and garlic oil.

Chocolate soufflé fondant heads up the desserts. The final touches are not quite up there with the best, and there is the definite sense that this is a chain restaurant – albeit a fine-dining one – but Bice remains one of the city’s safest bets for a good Italian dining experience.

We’ve found service over-attentive at Bellucci – probably because it’s normally frighteningly quiet. If you can forgive the flawed service, the food is pretty good. The minestrone soup is a densely populated broth of diced vegetables and plump beans, speckled with curved shavings of pungent parmesan, and the bresaola is curled in dark pink wisps of cured beef on a springy bed of green salad and is simply delicious.

The seafood tagliatelle is a fiesta of tangled green pasta ribbons, festooned with robust prawns, substantial squid rings, fleshy mussels and spidery baby octopus caught in a downpour of blustery tomato sauce. The lasagne bolognese is a comforting raft of softly layered pasta, beef and cheese that dissolves in the mouth in a flush of creamy indulgence.

It’s a puzzle why Bellucci is so empty when the food is so good, but the answer could lie in the desserts. The passionfruit sorbet is probably citrussy enough to be used as paint stripper, and the chocolate tart is as dry and chewy as a polystyrene model.

Skip desserts and you can have a fairly agreeable meal at Bellucci’s.

Bella Donna certainly seems more Italian than the rest of Mercato Mall. Meander over the bridges and past the fake pastel facades and to the restaurant. The sudden expanse of cream, black and chrome, fashionably angular furniture and pleasant outdoor terrace wouldn’t look out of place in Milan; sadly, while the surroundings may be stylish, the food is standard at best.

Even after a few hours’ hard shopping, it’s not worth filling up on the bruschetta, which is just tomato chunks on toast, lacking any of the oil or fresh basil needed to bring it alive. Dive instead straight into the carbohydrate fiesta that is the main course menu. The pasta seems to have lingered in the pan a little longer than it should have, so the chic white bowls of spaghetti and penne are no longer as toothsomely al dente as we would like. Rich sauces are generously endowed with cheese and cream, but overall a shortage of seasoning or fresh herbs leaves the dishes a little bland and it’s a feat to get through a whole portion. The pizzas are better with thin, crispy bases, fresh toppings and gloriously gooey cheese, but even they are searching for stronger, fuller flavours.

Among the desserts, the strawberry tart is an indulgent, syrupy patisserie-style affair, but if you’re just looking for an energy boost before a cinema trip or another onslaught on the shops, stick to a fresh smoothie – the berry affair is a wonderful purple concoction that manages to be fruity and creamy without being over-sweet. Or lose yourself in the coffee menu, which comes from the linked branch of Second Cup next door and includes every variety imaginable, including an excellent, seriously dark ‘house’ roast.

Bella Donna is an attractive and reasonably priced stop-off but not worth a special visit in its own right.

They say you can’t be all things to everyone, but Frankie’s has a fair stab at it. Conceived as an upscale diner with an inclusive vibe – families are positively welcome before 9.30pm – Frankie’s certainly lacks the snooty feel of so many of its rivals in Dubai.

The resulting atmosphere is buzzing and informal. The menu is what you might expect of an Italian restaurant abroad, but with a smattering of invention (presumably from the repertoire of Marco Pierre White, the nominal chef behind the business.

Speck-wrapped scallops with white bean sauce makes for a perfect starter, while the standard beef carpaccio and rocket is made special with a dash of delicious horseradish mousse.

Here and there mistakes creep in (over-salted spaghetti alle vongole, vaguely tough veal ossobuco), though the standards remain pretty high right through to dessert – particularly if you remember that Frankie’s was conceived as a family diner.

Service is slick and snappy (despite the crowds), the tinkle of lounge piano is soothing, and the atmosphere is conducive to return visits. If prices were a little lower, this place would be a real hit.

Allegria isn't so much a Cal-Italian restaurant as a bastion of traditional Italian cuisine that just happens to be located by the ocean in Malibu. The cooking is excellent and the setting is romantic (ask for a garden view when you book); all in all, it's well worth the 20-minute drive up the coast.

Recently renovated, Benvenuto offers quality, inexpensive Italian fare in its restaurant, a former recording studio (the Doors recorded LA Woman here). The front patio is great for people-watching. After dinner, head upstairs to the cosy cocktail lounge.

Calabasas is a bit of a backwater, but if you have business in Woodland Hills or the West Valley, consider coming here for the exceptional Italian food and seafood. The odd decor is left over from its previous incarnation as a Southwestern restaurant, but the sand dabs in lemon-caper sauce, the bison with port reduction and the pastas taste just as good when you're surrounded by Indian motifs.



If you're in the market for uncomplicated but superbly prepared Sicilian food served in an elegant setting, Celestino Drago would like to make your acquaintance. Drago's Pasadena location is famed for its excellent pastas, among them excellent pumpkin tortelloni with sage, but the menu also takes in other dishes. Reservations are essential.

Nobody goes to Dan Tana's for the cooking. It's not that the simple, old-fashioned Italian fare is bad: it's more that the old Hollywood atmosphere is wonderfully thick. The older servers can tell you what LA was like back when this food was cutting-edge, a time when they were much younger but Dan Tana's looked the same. It's favoured by celebs with respect for olde Hollywood (George Clooney, James Woods);

The best restaurant for several hundred kilometers. Zaitoun does modern Italian very well, with melt-in-the-mouth goat’s cheese, imaginative antipasto (like prawn and kiwi fruit), sizeable pastas and decent house plonk. The setting is low lit, and the decor a kind of modern European with Arabic hints. It’s very comfortable, and a welcome culinary surprise so far from the big city.

There aren’t too many establishments in the capital where Romanian cuisine thrives. Fewer still where Vlad the Impaler makes a personal appearance on the menu. This probably doesn’t help lure in the weak-stomached who might shy away from some of the gorier aspects of Romanian cuisine (stomach being one of those dishes on offer). However, upon closer inspection, Transilvania is a clean and well-appointed gaff with a menu that errs on safer and more familiar Italian territory. But when in Rome (or indeed Romania), it rather goes against the grain not to sample the local cuisine.

The platou romanesc is a typically sturdy example of cold turkey, salami and some of the saltiest cascaval cheeses you’ll ever find. The ostropel de puicupiure – slices of chicken smothered in a mild tomato sauce – is largely satisfying, but doesn’t stick in the memory long. It seems the dishes here are more practical than imaginative and the flavours might not be as bold as you’d expect. However, Transilvania’s novelty factor goes a long way in compensating for its shortcomings and is well worth a visit.

At the end of the meal, a cappuccino arrives decorated in so fine a cobweb design, it’s impossible to do anything other than sit and gawp. Anyone would be too frightened to disturb such splendour. Sadly, it’s the only point during the meal to express anything near finesse. While the food is capable enough at Sevilo’s, it’s never anything more than that, and you quickly start looking around for other ways with which to redeem your evening. Like taking a seat on the balcony, for example.

Sevilo’s stands out for having a city centre feel, positioned low enough to enjoy the enormity of the buildings around you, high enough to feel elevated from the pulse of street life beneath you. Unfortunately, the service is as frustrating as the meal itself, with waiters flapping about, whipping your plate away while you’ve still got food on your fork. It’s a shame because this modestly elegant restaurant looks like it could offer so much more.

Perhaps partly due to its slightly dilapidated surroundings, the Marina on Al Bateen Creek is starting to look a little underused, which is a shame as this pleasant restaurant could do with a little more patronage. Granted, things start picking up a little later in the evening, but the empty tables that greet you earlier on are a sorry sight. If that’s not enough to sour the atmosphere, the reams of bored staff lining the walls like mannequins most certainly will. Again, it’s a real pity as the food is recommendable and the location, while out of the way, makes for a very pleasing dinner. If decent pizza and pasta can’t be eaten overlooking a Venetian canal, then a quayside table, with sea and hull colluding beneath you, is a happy alternative. All in all, a decent trattoria, secluded and private enough for a romantic evening out, providing you can ignore the wallflowers.

Extremely popular with locals and expats alike, Prego’s can occasionally be difficult to book into, despite its impressive size. If you can, book a table on the terrace. Even though, at the time of writing, the view is obscured by the ongoing developments on Al Reem Island, it’s still a fairly chic place to be. Once the construction is finished, Prego will certainly be notable for its cushy setting. Keep an eye open for the one-off menus that turn up when a guest chef rolls into town; alternatively, make the most of the regular, well-thought-out options that currently prove so popular.

Prego does an especially naughty tortellini, and the ravioli, spaghetti and risotto are each served with an extra sprig of imagination that sets it a shoulder or two above many of its rivals, ensuring the reservations list keeps overloading. If there’s one thing that doesn’t do much for its reputation, it’s the desserts, but you’d have to be a glutton to get that far anyhow. Polish off a starter and a main and you’ll be more than satisfied, though getting through the front door again may prove a little difficult.

Su Sazzagoni is an Italian classic bar, an English coffee shop and a Sardinian delicatessen and trattoria. This concept being very normal in Sardinia and is now available here in Victoria Park Village. You can come for an English/Sardinian or continental breakfast, a panino or a slice of cake, cheese or bread. From lunch time until late we will offer cooked food to eat in or take away, the menu will change depending upon the seasons as it is important that all our ingredients are fresh. In the evenings we organize, what in Italy is called, “aperitivo party” you can come in for an early evening drink and will find a selection of appetizers laid out on the bar, for free. (small tasty bites) As in all Sardinian bar’s we will be selling a good selection of Sardinian wine by the glass and the bottle. All our wines can be purchased additionally from the delicatessen to take away.

During the week we will organize the “cena agrituristica” this is a special set menu which consists of about 10 courses and includes bread wine and coffee. This is very popular with the locals of Sardinia, and more and more the tourists are beginning to appreciate it.

Coffee, cappuccino, caffelatte, chocolate, juices, and a selection of cakes and Panini. From 6.30 until 7.30pm: aperitivo time- You buy the drinks, we offer a selection of appetizers for free.

From 11.00am until late: there will be a selection of freshly cooked food to take away such as pasta, rice, meat, fish, vegetables, and the chefs speciality ‘Su Sazzagoni’ desserts and cakes.
Restaurant/Trattoria: Always open for lunch and dinner 7 days a week. On Monday to Friday we have the addition of the fixed price lunchtime menu, which includes a soft drink or glass of wine. In the past every Florentine neighborhood had a fiaschetteria, a place where people would gather for a quick lunch, and where a segment of the population would pass the afternoons drinking wine by the flask. San Frediano was a poor neighborhood and had several, all hole-in-the-wall type joints whose clientele began to age inexorably in the 70s, as the younger generation adopted other pastimes. The one on the corner of Piazza del Tiratoio boarded up its doors about 10 years ago while the owners unleashed the stonemasons, and emerged about a month later as the Antico Ristoro di Cambi, an elegant eatery catering primarily to the lunch crowd. They still sell wine, of course, but now it's accompanied by a wide variety of salads, first courses, and entrées, things to be eaten by people on the go who don't want to slow down after lunch. I had pappa al pomodoro, a delicious dish made with fresh tomatoes, basil, and day-old bread that was spiced just right, followed by a "springtime salad," which was actually a platter with tomatoes, radicchio, mozzarella, thin slices of pecorino and some bresaola (cured beef drizzled with oil and lemon juice). Tasty, and since the items were distinct the flavors didn't run together.

Elisabetta, on the other hand, had had a heaping bowl of fresh salad and tripe salad, tripe served with thinly sliced fresh tomato and seasoned with olive oil, vinegar, salt and pepper. Both quite good. You can, if you want, order a steak -- the guy behind us did and appeared to be enjoying it, and in the winter the menu changes to reflect the cooler temperatures, with more rib-sticking entrées such as beans and sausage.

The cost? Betty and I spent 39,000, but didn't drink any wine (too hot). If you want something simple, quick and quite Florentine, you should try this.

The busy Grassmarket area attracts a mix of tourists, revellers and locals, and the same can be said of this family-run establishment. It claims to offer a true taste of Italy, and that starts from the moment you are greeted by one of a clutch of waiters with accents as strong as Gennaro's espresso. Tables in the front dining area enjoy the buzz of the venue, while the atmosphere in the rear section is slightly more subdued. Antipasti feature classic Italian dishes such as caprese, a whole buffalo mozzarella with the usual tomato and basil accompaniment, or select from a range of bruschetta – the capangnola is a delicious mix of peppers, olives and capers served cold on warm toast. Alongside pizzas and pasta, other traditional options populate the list of main courses, with vitello saltimbocca that ticks all the boxes, or a mildly spicy chicken diavolo. Meat dishes are served with chips and a rather limited salad, which is overpowered by celery. Desserts feature a chilled lemon or orange filled with ice-cream that is a refreshingly light finale, or you could go native and choose the tartufo classico, a zabaglione centre coated with chocolate that is loyal to its Italian roots.

A bright red sign pronouncing the restaurant's whereabouts cheerfully stands out amid Elm Row's other established businesses, beckoning in passers-by from the bustle of the town centre. The interior is dark and slightly worn by contrast, but incoming diners are greeted cheerfully by a moustached Mona Lisa and pleasant staff. Owner Vito Alongi can be seen flitting between tables, attending to those who need service or simply greeting regulars – of which there are many; a joking altercation over a favoured table is a pleasant sight. The lunch deal may be the reason for their loyalty, as three courses can be devoured for a meagre £5.30, and this menu is changed weekly. Log-fired pizza bases and unusual pasta shells in the main course stand out amid traditional toppings and sauces, although the dessert and starters are pretty standard. The a la carte menu verges on the large side, and can be a little confusing for those who find a wealth of choice impossible, though the dessert selection is a little average by comparison. Then again, after a particularly filling main lunch dish, dessert may be the furthest thing from your mind.

The Merchant Square might be as close as one can come to dining ‘al fresco’ in Glasgow, without being rained upon or bothered by passing locals. Diners can relax over a glass of wine at candlelit tables on the cobbled square. With the red-chequered tablecloths, professional waiting staff and light chatter from coming from the square, diners may be forgiven for thinking that they’re on the continent, instead of on Candleriggs. The menu bares the fruit of a typical Italian – pasta, pizza, veal, chicken and fish – but what the chef lacks in imagination he makes up for in skill. A generous starter of butterflied king prawns come bound in a deliciously sweet and chunky red pepper sauce, with rich flavours of garlic and chilli bursting through, served upon a sauce-soaked garlic crostini. A dish of mussels and king prawns tossed amongst fat strands of tagliatelle is bound in a rich, creamy sauce with sweet shallots and black pepper - a different take on the usual pomodoro sauce, but a satisfying one that works. And for dessert, a simple flavour of a traditional homemade cheesecake is livened up with a sweet, tangy forest fruit compote and lengthened with a hint of cinnamon.

The interior of Dunbarton Road’s Riviera Ristorante is decked out like an Italian courtyard. A beach-front is painted on one wall, as arched doorways and dark-wood panelling all lend themselves to the kitschy holiday feel. The staff are friendly and relaxed enough not to shatter the illusion, chatting happily to the customers and keen to give recommendations. The menu consists of Italian favourites cooked with an obvious knowledge of tastes and flavours. With a pre-theatre menu for just £7.95 for two well-cooked, high-quality courses, Riviera is surely offering one of the best early-dining deals the area has to offer. Starters include a rich and spicy penne arrabiatta, and fresh mussels cooked in garlic, white wine and parsley. The selection of main courses is equally generous - with around 15 options to choose from, it’s easy to see why Riviera has proven such a hit with locals.

Nestled on Causewayside, off the south-east tip of the Meadows, this humble little Italian restaurant produces dishes that are quite different – principally the ones that have a trademark shot of sambuca drizzled over them as they are served. The spirit is set alight so that the dish briefly blazes a brilliant blue. The liquor infuses into the creamy sauce, adding an unusual note of aniseed to contrast the flavour which works surprisingly well. Such special treatment is given to the split crayfish and the gamberoni (king prawns). Also available are various traditional pastas (as starter or main), pizzas and veal and chicken dishes. However, the fresh seafood dishes scream out as being the chef’s favourites and the ones to go for. Making good use of the top-quality Eddie’s Seafood Supplies nearby, the home-made lobster ravioli is scrumptious, and the tasty whole sea bream with a rustic cherry tomato sauce is reliably special. Opting for a coffee or a digestif is advisable as an alternative to dessert. A regular crowd of locals and students, who turn a blind eye to the desperate need for an interior revamp, come here to enjoy homely Italian food at reasonable prices.

Santini is the refined city cousin of Edinburgh’s other Italian eateries – a bit like up-market Milan compared to Modena or Messina. Don’t be fooled though; its crisp, smart, slightly clinical appearance masks the warm heart and generous disposition of an old family friend. The modern menu offers high-end versions of traditional pasta, risotto and pizza dishes alongside exotica such as papardelle di castagne al ragu’ di coniglio e funghi – thick ribbons of home-made pasta served with a buttery chestnut and mushroom sauce and chunky pan-fried rabbit. The secondi piatti are strictly meat and fish orientated, with beef and veal featuring heavily and salmon and sea bass making an appearance. The dolci are what really stand out though. Modern takes on traditional desserts such as tiramisu and panacotta sit beside specialities like a startling and moreish crema cotta al basilico – basil-flavoured burned cream served in an individual copper pan. The wine list is extensive and expensive, but cost appears to be of little consequence to Santini’s clientele of courting couples, business people and stout parents treating their grown-up children to a special meal. As Italian eating in Edinburgh goes, Santini is a little pricey by comparison, but worth every penny.

    
Qua may look like a trendy newcomer, but it’s actually a traditional Scottish Italian restaurant from a family team that have been behind the successes of some of Glasgow’s best-loved trattorias over the past 20 to 30 years. The extensive menu aims to provide simple traditional pasta and pizza dishes executed well, while also offering a more ambitious range of beef, veal and fish dishes. A trio of crostini made from homemade bread, are moistened with olive oil, and topped with sweet yet piquant roasted peppers, wild mushrooms and flavourful prosciutto, making a fitting and filling appetiser. The sogliola vellutata, a soft and moist fillet of sole resting in a pine nut-peppered puddle of sweet parmesan cream, is served with yielding asparagus spears and shows off the talent and experience of those in the kitchen. Coppa di Fiorentina, a decadent mix of homemade custard, cream, chocolate and liqueur-soaked sponge fingers is a substantial and decadent pudding, The stark modern architectural features of this corner of the Merchant City’s Todd Building have been tempered by the addition of natural wood and stone, and the genuinely friendly, attentive and efficient serving staff add to the relaxed atmosphere.


This impressive Merchant City venture models itself on the traditional enoteca - a wine bar that serves small plates of food, boasting an extensive wine menu with 24 wines served by the glass. The menu comprises Italian tapas-style offerings and has an almost overwhelming amount of choice. Each dish, no matter how small is individually prepared with time and effort. This takeaway is a real cheap and cheerful delight in an area where such things are not often appreciated nor expected. With over 20 pizzas on the menu, as well as a wide range of pastas, burgers and side orders, deciding what to have can be difficult. The corner of the Merchant City bounded by Ingram Street and Albion Street has become something of an unofficial Italian Quarter in recent years, with half a dozen Italian restaurants vying for business within a stone’s throw of each another. The increasing competition does not seem to have diluted the Italian Kitchen’s popularity, however. Indeed it remains one of the most perennially busy places to eat in the area. The spacious interior is bright and contemporary, and alongside the excellent, fast-paced service it creates an unmistakeably urban atmosphere. A la carte starters range from the well-constructed ‘bruschetta Italia’ with tomato, mozzarella di bufala, parma ham and rocket, to the disappointingly heavy and slightly undercooked fried aubergines in breadcrumbs with tomato sauce. There is a good choice of pizzas and the pasta menu is particularly strong. Tagliatelle with peas and ham is rich, nicely cooked and full of flavour. As with all the pasta dishes, the portion is enormous. More affordable daily specials, which might include sole goujon or steak burger with game chips, are also available.

Marcella's Italian Bakery is cheeky little retro café/takeaway that serves some of the best, and cheapest, pasta in town. The interior is cluttered and confusing, but the food on offer makes up for the rather eclectic surroundings. The lasagne is one of the most popular dishes, but owner Angelo Gibilisco recommends the spaghetti bolognaise.
