WORTH IT
THE SPACE A sweet, quirky and welcoming box of a room done in reds and pinks with lots of family photos scattered around — except in the pretty bathrooms, where photos of Sophia Loren (in the men’s room) and Ms. Loren with Marcello Mastroianni and other men (in the women’s room) dominate. Wheelchair accessible.
THE CROWD Mostly couples and groups of friends. Lots of chatting across tables and with the owner-chef, who spends a lot of time in the dining room.
THE BAR Thirteen predominantly red, mostly Italian wines by the bottle, from a $29 Chianti to a $90 Brunello di Montalcino; $7 to $8 for a limited offering of wines by the glass. Mixed and soft drinks available.
THE BILL Entrees from $22 to $30. Major credit cards accepted.
WHAT WE LIKED Roasted beets with mesclun and goat cheese (special), fried calamari, eggplant parmigiana, polenta with sausage and wild mushrooms (special), baked clams; rigatoni Bolognese, spaghetti and meatballs, pumpkin mascarpone ravioli (special), veal martini, chicken capricciosa, hanger steak; migliaccio, tiramisù, panna cotta, cannoli, brownie with vanilla ice cream.
IF YOU GO Open Tuesday, 5 to 10 p.m.; Wednesday and Thursday, 11:30 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 11:30 a.m. to 11 p.m.; Sunday, 11:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. Closed Monday. Reservations recommended on weekends. Street parking only.
RATINGS Don’t Miss, Worth It, O.K., Don’t Bother.
Four stars, for extraordinary, is the highest accolade a critic for The New York Times can award a New York City restaurant. Seven restaurants have that honor: Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s Jean Georges, Eric Ripert’s Bernardin (pictured above), Masayoshi Takayama’s Masa, Thomas Keller’s Per Se, Daniel Boulud’s Daniel, Danny Meyer's Eleven Madison Park and Del Posto, owned by Joseph Bastianich, Lidia Bastianich and Mario Batali.
Here are excerpts from the most recent reviews. Below them are the complete reviews.
Del Posto
Del Posto opened in 2005 on a wind-swept corner of that grim Manhattan neighborhood that is neither Chelsea nor the meatpacking district, in the shadows below what is now the High Line park. The restaurant’s owners, Joseph Bastianich, Lidia Bastianich and Mario Batali, and its chef, Mark Ladner, envisioned a temple to Italian cooking to match any ever built to honor a European cuisine in New York, a 24,000-square-foot palazzo of mahogany and marble devoted entirely to the pleasures of Italian food and customer satisfaction.
Five years later Del Posto is that and more, a place to sit in luxury and drink Barolo, while eating food that bewilders and thrills — an abalone carpaccio to start your meal, perhaps, and absolutely a celery sorbetto to end it, as well-played Gershwin and Kern tinkle in the background. — Sam Sifton, Sept. 29, 2010
Eleven Madison Park
Eleven Madison Park, which opened in 1998, now ranks among the most alluring and impressive restaurants in New York. It has reached this pinnacle because its principal owner, the indefatigable Danny Meyer, made a key move in 2006, bringing aboard the chef Daniel Humm, and because together they decided - out of pride, it seems to me, more than any commercial calculation — that this restaurant could and should shine as brightly as any other.
It already had the setting: that theatrically tall, marble and nickel-walled hall in the old Metropolitan Life Building, with grand windows onto the verdure of Madison Square Park. It already had a deep, broad wine list.
It just needed a bit more polish in its service and a lot more sparkle in its food. Over the last three and a half years, it has received precisely that. — Frank Bruni, Aug. 12, 2009
Daniel
Daniel was always fancy; now it’s genuinely gorgeous, too. And that’s almost reason enough to reaffirm the four stars the restaurant was awarded by William Grimes in The New York Times in 2001.
But the contemporary French menu and the service make their own contributions, usually measuring up to the extremely high standards the restaurant has established. All in all Daniel remains one of New York’s most sumptuous dining experiences. — Frank Bruni, Jan. 21, 2009
Jean Georges
Eating is seldom this absorbing, this bracing. To lend needed excitement to beef tenderloin, some foie gras had been placed on top. But the crucial, less predictable flourish was a rhubarb foam on top of that. It cut the fattiness of the liver. It snapped the palate to attention. So did a wedge of cured lemon that was strategically placed alongside broiled squab and foie gras in another dish. — Frank Bruni, April 19, 2006
Le Bernardin
Le Bernardin has aged with astonishing grace, more Deneuve than Dunaway, doing what it must to remain youthful without ever making an elastic fool of itself, staying true to its identity while adapting to changing times. Now as before, it is a high church of reverently prepared fish. But more than ever global currents inform and influence what emerges from a kitchen that can no longer be succinctly described as French. — Frank Bruni, March 16, 2005
Masa
Masa, despite its chosen peculiarities and pitiless expense, belongs in the thinly populated pantheon of New York's most stellar restaurants. Simply put, Masa engineers discrete moments of pure elation that few if any other restaurants can match. If you appreciate sushi, Masa will take you to the frontier of how expansively good a single (and singular) bite of it can make you feel. — Frank Bruni, Dec. 29, 2004
Per Se
It is not wondrous 100 percent of the time, and it can be maddening: at moments too intent on culinary adventure or too highfalutin in its presentation and descriptions of dishes, one of which came with a choice of four salts from three continents. To get a reservation may well require a degree of planning and effort that verge on masochistic, and a multicourse, mini-portion extravaganza may well require four hours, which is more time than many diners have or want to spend.
But here is the thing: the return on that patience and that investment is more than a few mouthfuls of food that instantaneously bring a crazy smile to your face and lodge in your memory for days and even weeks to come
HERE at long last is a winning new defense of fine dining: Ai Fiori, in the Setai Fifth Avenue hotel, just below Midtown. The chef and restaurateur Michael White opened the place late last year, with Chris Jaeckle in the kitchen and Ahmass Fakahany down at the bank. It is an emphatic rejoinder to the trend toward farmhouse tables, rustic food and shouting that has so dominated the dining scene in Manhattan at least since the start of the recession.
When one of the country's most respected and leading critics says that this restaurant is 'the best Italian Restaurant outside London' it is time to take them seriously. Britain's love affair with Italian food is a cause célèbre of long standing and shows no signs of waning, so it is always welcome news when somewhere like San Carlo sets out to reach for the skies. Located in the heart of Birmingham, San Carlo is well suited to catch both day and night time business, and the menu reflects this. There are 147 different dishes, plus blackboard specials, offering snacks, meals, celebrations, all in true Italian style, dishes that bring Italy into the very centre of life in Birmingham.
The stylish Piatto, situated in Ladypool Road, Birmingham, is popular in the area for its authentic Italian cuisine. The classy interior is done up in dark brown and white, with well laid out tables and large floor to ceiling windows that make the dining area bright and airy. Piatto's Italian chefs ensure they use quality ingredients from around the world and where possible from Birmingham, to create fresh dishes all from scratch. Appetizers of salads, mushrooms cooked in garlic butter and garnished with mozzarella cheese; and smoked salmon with prawns and Marie Rose sauce help set the stage for the main course. Pizza, pastas such as the chef's special risotto al pollo of Italian rice with chicken and fresh greens; a choice of grills that could include sirloin steak; strips of chicken breast with peppers, and a platter of mixed fish that delights lovers of seafood can be had as mains.
For years, this posh Chelsea address was synonymous with high-end modern French cuisine: as Aubergine, it was Gordon Ramsay’s training ground, & later it thrived with William Drabble in the kitchen. Following the recent closure of the purple-hued Gallic grandee, 11 Park Walk has re-emerged waving the Italian tricolore. Its new incarnation touts flexibility, so drop by for a plate of homemade pasta (perhaps saffron pappardelle with pig’s cheek, chestnut tagliatelle or Sardinian malloreddus with artichokes & bottagra), or sample a leisurely dinner from the seasonally tweaked, regionally inspired menu. Traditional antipasti of cotechino with lentils or burrata with Sicilian caponata could give way to ‘black-ink’ cod with courgette purée, braised stinco d’agnello with mash, or venison with wild mushrooms & milky polenta. I love Caesar's Italian Restaurant!! This place is Old School. I've been coming here since I was a little girl. This place is still the BEST Family Style Italian Restaurant in San Francisco. If you are missing some Italian home cooking, you have to come here. 

The 7 course meal reminds me of the big family dinners. You get more than you can handle, but look forward to the next dish. I try so hard to make it to the entree, but by that time - I'm usually full.

I think I wasn't thinking straight when I decided to go all 7 rounds, but I wanted to impress the big guy with a big Italian Dinner without the family dinner, lol. Are you ready? Manga, Manga!!

1.) House Salad with Creamy Italian Dressing

2.) Antipasto Dishes: three bean salad, calamari, salami, potato salad, grilled eggplant. They bring out tons of dishes, pretty quickly the table is covered with them. 

3.) Vegetable Minestrone Soup, my fave - reminds me of my grandma's. Ask for Parmesan, it's necessary. 

4.) Pasta, a side order of Rigatoni with Meat Sauce. I almost couldn't make it through at this point, but I had help. :

5.) Your Main Entree with it's sides! At this point I'm full but ordered the Meat Lasagna. Laine ordered the Chicken Parmesan, the special of the Day. That was good too. My Lasagna was very good, creamy and the meat sauce is really tasty.  I was already stuffed and took the rest to go. The Lasagna was really great the next day. :)

6.) Once you have made it through, you are rewarded with scoops of ice cream. Pick from Raspberry Sherbet, Vanilla, Chocolate or Spumoni. 

7.) And Coffee. We were not really in the mood for coffee, but I always remember the after dinner coffee in my family. I think it's to balance the Food Coma you fall into. 

All of the Family Style Dinners are based on your main entree, from about $25. to $35 per person. Incredible value if you consider the amount of food served
New Year's is about celebrating the old, welcoming the new and cherishing the family.

Caesar's is an old institution that opened its doors to San Franciscans in 1956.  If it is traditional Italian cuisine you want and the famed San Francisco dish, Cioppino, Caesar's is the place to go. http://www.yelp.com/bi... http://www.yelp.com/bi...

I was finally able to try Caesar's when fiance's sister and her husband took us to dinner here for fiance's birthday. The future brother in law is second generation Italian. Caesar's is his Italian parents and "nonna's" (Italian for grandmother) restaurant of choice for family get togethers. 

Fiance's sis whispered as we were sitting down, "you come here for the food and ambiance, not for the service."  Sure enough, Caesar's is packed and loud with multi-generational families--mostly Italians but diverse enough with Asians and other non-Italian families. "Godfather "would have been happy to bring his la famiglia here. 

If you want to practice your Italian, this is the place to do it.  The place was loud with Italian dialects spoken all around us.   Fiance's sis pointed out the staff who are from the old country who barely speak English but has been working at Caesar's for decades.  http://www.yelp.com/bi...

Caesar's is indeed old-school from the decor, immigrant restaurant staff and traditional Italian cuisine.  http://www.yelp.com/bi... The waiters wear black and white tux. http://www.yelp.com/bi... http://www.yelp.com/bi...

As much as I wanted to try the Cioppino, they were not serving it that night.  Future in-laws suggested that we go for the $35 Seven Course dinner. And for $35 per person, you will get plenty of delicious fare to get you stuffed:

1st Course: SALAD of lettuce, tomato and onionwith Italian dressing.

2nd Course: ANTIPASTI of calamari salad, garbanzo bean salad, grilled eggplant (caponata), cured ham, etc.  
*The dishes were fresh and delicious. Future bro-in-law's told us his nonna made these dishes for the family every Sunday. I could dine on these small dishes alone! I could not stop eating the garbanzo bean salad, caponata and calamari salad.

3rd Course:  A small dish of PASTA WITH MEAT SAUCE. 
*I ate around the meat sauce since I am a pescetarian. I would say that the sauce was very flavorful and definitely NOT Chef Boyardee's!

4th Course:  A delicious bowl of  lite MINESTRONE SOUP. 

5th Course:  Choice of main dish. 
*Fiance chose GRILLED LAMB CHOPS which he requested as well-done. It came to him medium rare. He said it was still delicious, not gamey and very tender. http://www.yelp.com/bi...

*I had the GRILLED SEAFOOD PLATTER. My  meal came with a skewer of plump prawns and very tender scallops with spinach and potatoes. As simple as my meal was, it was surprisingly very good! I had to take half of it home since I got stuffed from eating the antipasti,salad and soup. http://www.yelp.com/bi...

6th Course: SPUMONI. 
*You get to choose from their dessert menu but the spumoni was a great way to end this nice Italian dinner.

7th Course: COFFEE

OVERALL:
Service was polite and not so bad. This was a leisurely dinner and you might have to flag your server down once in a while.  They leave you alone but not forget about you. You will still get your water refilled and your dishes on time.  

They even gave my fiance an amaretti flavored cheesecake with a candle in it for his birthday dessert. Rich and delish!

I have traveled to Italy and have had the pleasure to eat well in Rome and the Umbrian region.  Caesar's is indeed authentic, traditional  and old school.  The dishes are not as delicious as what I had in Italy but at Caesar's it is about tradition. The dishes were simple, fresh and light--not the heavy, cheesy, Italian-American that is standard in the US. 

On our way out, fiance's sis spotted BUGIE COOKIES for sale at the counter. She said their nonna made these Italian sweets. I grabbed a couple of boxes for $6 each and gave one to her as a thank you present for the nice dinner treat.  Bugies I found out later are fried dough sprinkled with powdered sugar.  Delicious but not diet food! http://www.yelp.com/bi...

Thanks future sis-in-law and future bro-in-law for a delicious dinner.

If you ever wonder what it was like in your grandpa's lodge, the kind Fred and Barney used to go to get away from Wilma and Betty on "The Flintstones" when they were members of the Royal Order of Water Buffaloes, well, wonder no further. You can live out your fantasies of being the guest of honor at a Rotary Club banquet by coming to Caesar's. the biggest throwback to a 1950's-style social hall that I've ever seen in this city. Quality-wise, the food is definitely at the banquet level. So is the noise level. It's like eating in the middle of Grand Central Station terminal.

"Warehouse" is the first thought I had when I entered the place. They actually had mirrors on the wall that were supposed to look like windows. Curtains were painted on the beams. Naugahyde booths. Paper bibs for the crab legs. All the chintzy touches are here because it's Caesar's, goombah. Jamie W. and I came here on Friday since we didn't feel like waiting at Houston's, and I seem to recall that this eatery was praised on an episode of "Check Please! Bay Area". Granted the recommender was a silver-haired dandy wearing a white turtleneck, but what the hey? He looked trustworthy.

Well, service was hectic. I don't think the hostess ever looked at me as she muttered "How many?" and then looked immediately at her table map (see photo...nice perm!). We both decided to try their seven-course dining extravaganza. I went for the $29 Osso Bucco meal, and Jamie ordered the $25 Ravioli plate. I didn't know the routine, so the waiter just kept coming with small plates. First up was the paltry green salad ladled thick with some kind of creamy dressing. Along with it came a bowl of chickpeas, kidney beans and onions marinated in lemon and olive oil, which I assumed I was supposed to spoon over the salad.

But then he also came with slices of mortadella. Oh, but here comes the cherry tomatoes with mozzarella cheese balls and then a mix of calamari and button mushrooms. No complaints, but we were both getting kinda full from all of it. The steaming minestrone soup came out next in a big silver bowl, which was then ladled into our bowls by the waiter. By the time I dipped my spoon in, he was already back with the penne in ragout sauce. This was getting ridiculous because I didn't have room left for the osso bucco itself. It turns out that wasn't such a bad decision since it just wasn't that good compared to a place like Stelline in Hayes Valley. The meat was rather dried out despite all the chunky tomato sauce poured on top of the shanks.

Only one of the shanks had any marrow, which was a major bummer, and I barely ate two of the three shanks on the plate. Jamie could barely touch his ravioli since it was virtually the same as the penne he just had. Feeling bulimic, I excused myself only to return to see a parfait glass filled with spumoni with the green dye streaked throughout. I licked it up, maraschino cherries and all. Ugh. We were so full I could barely move from the table, Meanwhile, the restaurant was packed with families, senior citizen groups and beer-bellied paisans looking for a little amore. If you want to eat yourself in a coma, Caesar's may fit the bill if your idea of good eats is assembly-line Italiano.

TOTAL - 3 stars...if quantity trumps all, then go, my porky paisan, go!

This restaurant must be one of my favorites! When people come to San Francisco and ask me where the best place to get some delicious food, I immediately answer with Caesars Italian Restaurant.

As you enter the restaurant, you are immediately greeted by the welcoming employees and seated. The environment itself is very calm and relaxing-- great for a nice dinner after a long day. Not to mention that the restaurant is conveniently located by Fisherman's Wharf where I like to explore the shops and end the day with a nice meal from Caesar's.

During a recent lunch, someone asked about authentic cioppinos in the city and only two immediately came to mind:  a) Little Joe's and b) Caesar's.  With this thought firmly in my mind, I gathered some friends for a casual Friday get-together.  It's been a while since I've had the famed Crab Cioppino, served Tuesdays to Fridays.  When reading the specials and the price, I thought the numbers were transposed as it was only $23.00 the last time I had it, but crab is out of season right now so I should have expected it.  Here is what I had:

Appetizer
Manhattan Clam Chowder - This is my preferred version as the New England version (creamy) is more commonly found.  Just the right balance of okra, chopped clams, and potatoes with a tangy flavor.  Great on those cool foggy nights.  - $4.50

Fried Calamari (shared) - Golden brown fried calamari pieces, large chopped rings that came to the table hot.  The flavor was good, but it would have been better if it had a mix of the other pieces (tentacles and such).  The server also forgot to bring either tartar, cocktail, or marinara sauce.  I requested marinara sauce as the squid pieces quickly cooled, hoping that the warm sauce would hi-lite the flavor.  Success.  - $13.00

Pasta - A small plate of rigatoni in a delicious meat sauce comes with every fish or meat entree.  Be sure to generously sprinkle their parmesan cheese on this...  It was so good that we considered asking for an extra side order to share.  - free

Entree
Crab Cioppino - A large heaping bowl filled with mostly dungeness crab pieces, mussels, clams, and calamari in a tomato broth; two large garlic bread slices accompany this order.  Not for diners who expect to exclusively use utensils as you'll need to battle the shells to enjoy the luscious local trademark crabmeat.  The shelling bowl came in very handy as the pile barely fit the bowl for two orders.  - $32.00.

Dessert
Fried Bow Ties (complimentary) - A family style plateful of deep fried batter covered with powdered sugar.  Being stuffed from overindulging on the garlic bread and regular bread, I only ate two pieces.  

The dining room was about 80% full, but their private party room was packed.  The service was very homey, but a bit slow due to the high volume of customers; it was a mix of tourists, couples, local families, and small groups like ourselves.  The servers were good about refilling the glasses, with the minor glitch being the calamari sauce issue.  The bread initially came cold/hard, but, when we requested hot bread, the waiter quickly brought some.  The owner walked the room to make sure everything was okay with all the diners.  
If you get a craving for cioppino, this place definitely delivers, but be prepared to pay for it.
I like the overall vibe of the place, the old bar is cool and it definitely feels like a traditional Italian American family run restaurant.  That said, there are several things that could be improved upon.

To begin with the wine was terrible, which I should have known when I saw the wine list which didn't specify any wines they served by the glass.  Instead it seems they have Costco sized bottles of the all the wines listed (which was an entire page) which they  open and use until it's gone.  I have a hard time believing that they go through all those wines quickly enough to be able to do that.

I ordered the Insalata Caprese, which they for some reason they call Tomatoes with Mozzarella Cheese on the menu.  My sister was thinking of getting it, but was understandably confused considering the odd wording and asked if it was a salad.  I said yes knowing what it's called and knowing that "insalata" literally translates to "salad," not a huge leap.   Our waiter cut me off and said no, it was an antipasto.  I'm sorry if he can't get his head outside of the American "a salad involves lettuce" box but as a waiter he should come to realize that a salad is not defined by the presence of lettuce. 

I have to say the Porcini Fettuccini I got was really good, but considering how many Italian restaurants there are in North Beach alone I'll try another one before going back to Caesar's.

Came to Caesar's over in SF North Beach just last Friday night.  On Friday nights, there is a lively vibe, at least last Friday night a fortnight from Christmas Eve.  The place was decorated nicely for the holidays and there's a boisterous social energy in the place though the sound a little too loud for me.

The bar had what appeared to be an extremely lively happy hour and what struck me was that everyone there were much older, couples in their 60s and 70s but having what seemed like a great time.  Just as I walked in, some older man was talking to me as if I were his friend for many years before I even knew it!  I wasn't too taken aback.  I mean, who hasn't been warm to complete strangers on a happy hour Friday after drinking for two hours?

The only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars is because the friend I came here with really enjoyed the place because he loves it when they keep bringing in endless amounts of bread and butter.  Also, they goofed when we made a reservation and when we arrived our booth was given to someone who walked in and the gave us complimentary glasses of Chianti to make up for it.  And the Chianti was pretty good.

But I don't rate establishments based on bread or "make-up for the screw up" service.  Things like that make a four star place a five star place.

The service here is fairly reasonable too, though a little shady to me for some reason.  Any place where people assume I am Italian because my name is Tony is usually a suspicious sign that the establishment is a cheap Italian restaurant lacking true quality Italian food.  

I notice that about Italians.  If they act nice to you, they're ripping you off or screwing you over in one fashon or another.  If they act arrogantly or cold around you, they offer quality food that is usually out of this world.  It's like that in Italy too.

In the future, I'll have to hop to hop from one Italian restaurant to Italian restaurant.  The first place where they appear reserved and arrogant, I will sit down and order.

For $40 (including tip):

1.  I had an order of their clam chowder which was actually not bad but it was not Boston style and more of a Manhattan Clam Chowder.  Still not too bad.

2.  The bread and butter was ok.  At least it wasn't stale.

3.  Also included was appetizers,at $6.50 (for my share), we had fried calimari which I thought was nasty.  It was too doughy and tasted as if it had been cooked in grease that was 5 days old.

4. The entree, the most important part of the meal was downright horrible.  I had Lasagne.  How could an Italian restaurant mess up so badly?  What really grossed me out about it was that the mozarella cheese had that ugly melted look as if it melted and then got cold and looked sweaty.  That signals to me that it probably had been microwaved and then had just been sitting there for at least 5-10 minutes.  I only ate half of it and tossed it when I left the place.  It lacked flavor or love or anything that justified the $16 price tag for it.  Very disappointed.

All in all, I left the place thinking: another horrible Italian restaurant in the tourist infested Italian neighborhood.

It's very hard finding good Italian food in the US let alone the Bay Area.  If you find one in SF, please let me know and I'll give it a shot.

This is really about a 2.25 star place but I bumped it up slightly as a courtesy and because my friend enjoyed the place.
Very disappointing. 

The a la carte pasta was penne in a runny meat sauce. Cafeteria food. When the waiter asked me why I didn't eat it, I told him that tomatoes gave me heartburn. He replied "Well, it's a meat sauce" seemingly oblivious that the base of the sauce consists of tomatoes.

I ordered a New York strip steak, and was served a fairly substandard, tasteless grade of beef. I probably could have gone across the street to Safeway and bought a better steak. Rarely have I NOT finished a steak, but I left about a quarter of it when I realized I was choking it down. Whoever categorized this restaurant as a steakhouse needs to be shot.

The atmosphere is kitschy, but you know that when you first walk in. However, the linoleum floors and the lack of any sound baffling on the walls will make for a loud experience when the dining room gets busy. It's even worse when they start turning up the constant drone of Frank Sinatra's Greatest Hits which made me want to tear the speakers out of the wall.

I definitely won't be going back.

After reading reviews from other Groupon users, it was with some slight trepidation that we went along to Al Dente on a Monday night. However, we found it to be the opposite of what other people had experienced. We were given a basket of lovely warm bread to eat as we looked through the menu. To be honest, as we are both vegetarian we only looked at the meat-free stuff so can't comment on the rest of the meals but ours were very tasty. I can recommend the gnocchi in a cheese sauce, topped with caramelised leeks, and a there was a huge amount of it too. I wasn't going to have a dessert but after seeing they had a walnut and honey tart with ice cream, I couldn't resist. it was wonderful. As my husband is a cheese fan he went for the italian cheeses and said they were one of the best he had ever had. The service was fine, there was just the one waiter working that night and he managed to keep everyone happy. We will definitely be going back to this restaurant. 
Unlike other Groupon reviewers who didn't seem to have clue about good food we were pleasantly surprised. We eat out a lot but like many people have favourite restaurants we stick to. Groupon was a way for us to maybe venture further. We had no expectatations, if didn't come up to scratch of where we usually eat it didn't matter as was a bargain price.
We were very pleasantly suprised though at the high standards if the meal.
I am addicted to cheese so chose the mozzarella starter from the specials board which my husband had what I initially was going to have, saute de pesce which was mixed seafood. The cheese was bought and made locally and each different mozzarella was gorgeous BUT not as amazing as the seafood of which my poor husband only had half due to me helping myself. The squid so easy to get tough was soft the prawns fair sized and tasty and the sauce JUST seasoned right.
My husband had the belly pork and the skin was just crispy and the meat melted in the mouth. This though was nothing to compare to the coniglio in porchetta. I was worried either one if the meat would be too strong. Rabbit can be but also salami can take over. Neither on this occasion, the terrine of meat in the medallions all complemented each other the pancetta giving it the subtle almost cream like taste.
Both if us had mash potatoes which was was lovely using again the best of ingredients and plenty of butter a truly luxurious puree, not your average dried milky glutenous rubbish here. The vegetables just the right amount and again as everything else cooked to perfection
We didn't have dessert as we both don't really have sweet tooths so always reluctant to try plus we usually only have two courses.
The only other thing I have to comment on was the service. The waiter was well informed, and recommended drinks that suited us both and the chef as well as being excellent chef was friendly a truly amazing personality.
My only negative was for designated drivers soft drinks were unbelievably expensive a small glass of coke was £2. My recommended Merlot though was smooth and buttery.
We WILL be going back, we WILL be recommending and here I thoroughly recommend this hidden Edinburgh treasure. Sp thank you Groupon and thank you Al Dente

Having spent several holidays in different parts of Italy we were delighted to discover this little Italian gem not too far from the centre of the town. The waiter/owner, Graziano, makes you feel very welcome and we could not fault the service, the quality of the food or the cleanliness of the place. We also met Graziano’s lovely wife and charming little daughter.
In true Italian style we were giving a basket of bread and oils to dip in while we waited for our food to be freshly cooked. I had a mixed seafood starter and my husband cleared his plate of sardines stuffed with pine nuts - and never found any bones. For mains we both chose the veal with parma ham which came artistically presented with a good variety of finely cut vegetables, including my favourite, tempura courgette.
All washed down with a nice chilled bottle of Frascati. No room for dessert but had coffee instead. We had a voucher but would have happily paid full price for this meal and will certainly be back again. 
We chose to dine at Al Dente as we received a voucher and i tend to like local Italians. To find a diamond you need to trawl through the rough - well this was the rough!
We'd walked quite a way to get there, so before I looked at the menu I fancied a glass of wine and a bowl of olives or bread. This wasnt an option - we had to order the drinks at the same time as the food, and there would be no food before the starter, I was sternly told. It was immediately apparant many people had the same voucher as me, and table turning was the main priority of the evening.
We ordered a bottle of white treibanna - reasonanly priced and easy drinking. We then got starters - both seafood dishes. Mine was simple but the fish was cooked quite well and the sauce was nicer than it looked. However there was endless bits of gristle and bone which made the meal more of a chore then a pleasure. My partner could not even touch his sardines for fear of choking.
The main course - the speciality rabbit rish - was laughingly poor. The smell when it came over set the tone, it really couldnt be described as anything but feet. The rabbit was stuffed with chorizo and other spicy meats but it was inedible. The meat was tough and fatty and the spicy sausages so strong and clashed with the rabbit. The mashed potato was just slop and how they burnt carrots I shall never know. It has been a long time since I have not managed to finish a meal - I could barely start this one.
I ordered the cheese board for dessert as i'd had a craving for cheese since I knew I was going there for my dinner. We ordered it, but decided quickly we couldnt face any more food - paid and made a quick exit.
We went there with our ten year old son on the advice of the local bar tender, and had an excellent meal, one of the best we have had at Edinburgh. Takes about a twenty to thirty minute walk (we did it in the rain) from the center of Edinburgh where most tourists hang out. There was some construction going on outside the building, but the restaurant is open and perfectly quiet and cozy. Great service, efficient and friendly without being too friendly. Great food and wine, not overly pretentious but very fresh and good, at a very decent price. And if this still doesn't convince you, while we ate there, we watched two local Italian families come in for a meal. Plainly the native Italians in Edinburgh think it is the place to go.

I would not normally write reviews for restaurants as often my experience is the same: average-poor food at ridiculous prices.
However, this restaurant made my family's trip to Edinburgh worthwhile.
The food was fantastic- simple but delicious and inventively presented.
The pasta I had was cooked to perfection- truly 'al dente', with a homemade pesto sauce which tasted fresh and succulent.
On that night, I was not feeling particularly hungry, so opted for the half portion.
Not only was it equally delicious as a full portion, but it represented great value- the portion was very reasonable for its low price.
Also, the starter I shared (bruschetta with different toppings) was again very simple and again really delicious!
The apple strudel and ice cream both seemed homemade and were very enjoyable.
The atmosphere was relaxing, with italian music playing which really took me to Italy.
The waiter was attentive and helpful without interfering or interrupting the meal.
Overall, the £60 I paid for three people, including three main meals, one desert and two glasses of wine was great value and some of the best food I have ever eaten.
Definitely 5*, and worthy of a michelin star in my opinion.  
If you are planning a trip to Edinburgh, you MUST eat here. No question. We booked having reviewed previous comments on Tripadvisor. This is a small gem about 5 minutes in a taxi from Princes Street. It has the feel of an Italian restuarant in Italy - rather than in the UK. This is always a good sign - so if modern decor, table fashion and miniscule portions of food are what you seek, then Al Dente is not the place for you. Which is a shame because the food is simply the best you will find anywhere. The menu is simple but authentic, the plates were full, and the flavours beat anything I have experienced in over 30 years of dining Italian in the UK. The mushroom risotto, and frutta di mare tagliatelle starters, plus the chicken main course, were wonderfully cooked by the chef Antonello (?), and the tiramisu to follow was the best ever. Graziano, as host, has been trading for less than 2 years but fully deserves the overall rating within Tripadvisor. He was excellent and was passionate about his business, including his policy of using only the best local produce. We shall definitely return when next in town.

I had probably the best risotto and fillet steak i've ever tasted, delicious!

Al Dente is an excellent, friendly, homely and truly Italian dining experience not to be missed. The chef and waiter run it together, planning a menu from a different region of Italy for a special feast each month, the most successful dishes making it on to the ever-changing menu. Pre-booking is mostly not necessary but is necessary for these monthly menus. I have never been disappointed, which I cannot say for any restaurant I have been to in Italy!

I don't know why so many Italian and Greek restaurants try to give an impression of authenticity with lots of pseudo-classical columns and statues. This restaurant provides real authenticity and the atmosphere of a contemporary Italian trattoria. The Italian music playing in the background is tasteful, avoiding the syrupy, sentimental stuff one often associates with Italy. And most importantly the food is great. My wife and I had antipasti consisting of swordfish carpaccio and calamari stuffed with vegetables; the mains were lamb steak in a wine and rosemary sauce and lemon sole, and we finished up with a couple desserts (including a delicious tiramisu and a peach sorbet) and a plate of Italian cheeses, all accompanied by a nice bottle of the house white, a wine from the Veneto region several classes better than the cheap washed-out wines that region produces in lamentably large volumes. Service was great, and the owner (from the Puglia region) obviously puts a lot of heart and thought into what he is doing. In all, if you want a nice Italian dinner in Edinburgh, this is the place to go. 
On a warm May evening my husband, a friend and myself stepped into Tuscany via the magic portals of Al Dente, the Easter Road restaurant owned by the very welcoming and charming Graziono Spano. This was the second of Graziano’s themed evenings designed to introduce diners to authentic regional Italian cuisine accompanied by carefully chosen wines. The small restaurant has been enlivened by a plethora of photographs, including Graziano’s native Bari in the South of Italy and by fresh roses on the tables.
After canapés and prosecco we had caciucco alla Livornese, a traditional dish of shell fish and fish in tomato sauce – absolutely delicious, as was the white Galestro wine Graziano served as an accompaniment. This was followed by a prima patti of homemade pasta and duck ragout (pappardella al ragu di anatra). The rose wine (rosa di ninfa) which accompanied the pasta dish was my absolute favourite. It really had the aroma and taste of strawberries!
The arista di maiale con rosmarino (pork loin with rosemary, served with artichokes and roast potatoes) which followed melted in the mouth. The potatoes were particularly tasty and I’d love the recipe. This was served with a full bodied Chianti. How did I cope with all this food, you may ask? I simple ate a little of every course, while many of the diners cleared their plates with relish.
The zuccotto sweet of light sponge cake with white chocolate and nuts was the perfect desert and the Il santo wine complemented it perfectly. It was an exquisite conclusion to the Tuscan banquet – Graziano’s answer to “Babette’s Feast”.
Graziano was the perfect host, telling us about the wines, keen to hear what we thought of the food created by chef Antonello. After coffee I floated up Easter Road full of the light, warmth and sheer joy of Italy – as well as all that wonderful food.
The menu, including wines and coffee cost £38 per person. The next theme night features the Lazio region and will be on 29th May. See you there! 
Went to this tiny eaterie for Saturday lunch. It is on the site of the old Tinnelli restaurant on Easter Road, which I always meant to go to but never did.
It had advertised a set lunch Tuesday to Saturday(£7.95 I think) previously but this is now only available Monday to Friday. Nonetheless, having heard from friends that it was worthy of a visit we decided to try it out.
We were welcomed by the proprietor Graziano Spano who hailes from Bari on Italys Adriatic coast. A limited number of tables are available so if your heart is set I would book ahead.
The style is modern italian. Cooked by the Chef Stefan,
from Rimini & the food did not disappoint. I started with Smoked Salmon which was a special (£5.50 for a fairly large serving)& came with rocket, parmesan & garlic bread. Graeme had the soup of the day(£2.95), Cream of pea & ham, which also came with a slice of garlic bread. It looked great so I had to have a taste. Wonderful!! We both opted for the Lasagne de Pesce for our second course, sheets of lasagne pasta with a scallops king prawn & mushroom sauce. Fantastico! At £7.20 we didn’t expect this to be a huge portion, so took the descision to order a mixed salad to share also. Glad we did as this rounded it off nicely. This was washed down with a bottle of the very respectable house white, and a bottle of still water. The bill came to around £43.00
The service was great, Graziano was assisted by a rather nervous wine waiter from Naples, who settled into his role as the service went on. We think it must have been his first day. The space is small & cosy, the kitchen tiny & the food brilliant. I would urge you to try it out. 
Unfortunately a mixed bag. On a positive note, all the staff were excellent and deserve high praise as they were extremely attentive and friendly. However, the kitchen didn't manage to maintain this high standard. For a start, portions are inconsistent as they range from average to small (even for the same bloody dish!!) which isn't good enough considering the A la carte prices are in the average to high category. In fact, if I had been picking up the tab myself (father-in-laws treat) the plates would have been returned to the kitchen immediately for rectification. Biggest disappointment was inconsistency with the flavours. Starters, bruschetta pomodoro, tomatoes like turnips, lacking in salt, no balsamic, just very poor and lazy. Unsure if chef has no palate, or using cheap ingredients to save money (or both), but not good enough as I buy nice sweet vine ripened tomatoes myself from the supermaket and I'm a bloody amateur!. Lasagne & Pasta Carbonara, extremely good indeed. Calzone, great flavour from filling, very poor texture of cooked dough (the acid test). So, not sure if this is a restaurant on the way up or way down, but based on this inconsistent performance I get the impression that the lack of competition in the Inverurie area is letting the owner get lazy with the standards. Not bad, but with some attention to detail could be miles better.

I see my last review of this restaurant is almost 18 months old. As I live locally, I've probably been 4 times since then, the latest being last night. I don't usually do multiple reviews but, in view of some of the negative comments, I feel that, for balance, I should add that I have never been less than fully satisfied here. I usually dine "a la carte" but last night I had the "special menu" of 3 courses with prosecco, olives and bread for £22. Enough choice and the food was tasty and well-cooked, excellent value at that price. As usual we discussed wines with the manager - I like his enthusiasm - and were very happy with his recommendation of a Calabrian red, not unreasonably priced at £36 given its quality. Personally I have always found the service polite and efficient and last night was no exception. Last night it was pretty busy so the "atmosphere" was more lively than it sometimes is. One plus of this restaurant is that the tables are well-spaced, so no danger of putting your elbow in the plate of a diner at the next table or inadvertently joining in their conversation ! I shall happily return.

The maitre d' was off hand at the start [we never saw him again], the waiters could do nothing right; they provided a dish of olive oil but no bread, this came when requested after the starter; they dropped a plate; they failed to see that I did not have a knife and fork for the main course; delivered two plates of cakes and left them until reminded that they were for the table next door; failed to give that table any cake plates until reminded. As for the food it was not what you expect for £20 a head. In particular the chips with the chicken were soggy and could well have been frozen. Judging from other reviews there was something seriously amiss with front of house on this occasion but since I will not be returning I cannot say whether it was due to a single glitch or a systemic problem. 
Service was good if a little too attentive - the staff tended to 'hover' too much. We were pushed for time as we had booked to go to the Proms for 7pm but had we had more time we'd probably have complained about the food. 1 person in the party had seabass which was good and the other two had pasta which was supposedly with crab - well stingy is not the word, we had a few tiny flakes of crab and the rest was pasta, overall it was pretty bland and unexciting considering the price - with 1 bottle of wine and a bottle of water and no starters/desserts we paid £100. Not good value for money. Best thing about the place is the decor, it's quite classy. But for food, rather disappointing. I would not go back. 
I was very pleasantly surprised! I went to Cafe Pasta not really expecting too much and left having all but licked my plate clean! My bowl of pasta was cooked well with the correct amount of sauce i.e. just coating the pasta and not swimming in sauce as seems to be the case at many other Italian restaurants. The food was tasty, arrived in good time and was well priced. It's not the sort of place where every morsel delights the tastebuds but it's definitely recommended for an easy, quick and satisfying dinner. 
This is a good Italian restaurant, not exceptionally authentic, but ok for pizza and pasta. Good prices, can be slow in busy times. 
This is a small and cosiest restaurant in the whole of Chiswick. The place is family run and provides the most authentic Italian i have ever tasted in London. Rumour has it, that their mozzarella is flown in every other day and you can really see it, particularly on their pizzas, as it is a real and true and one and only Fior Di Latte! We go there quite often, so it is difficult to choose the dishes that i would like to recommend. But, my favourite is - Paccheri Alla Partenotea, my three year old daughter will die for Mellenzane alla Parmiggiana, my husbands favourite is Buffalo Fillet Steak. Also, one thing about their bread - it is NOT over salted, which seems to be a cheap=p trick a lot of Italian restaurants use ... So for me as a mum with 2 small children this restaurant is a piece of haven which believe me is not an easy find.

I visited Canta Napoli on wednesday 20th January, late afternoon/ early evening. What a fantastic place! I popped in for a quick coffee, which was absolutey delicious and ended up sampling some pizza marinara which was divine. I was most impressed with the welcome that the staff showed to young children, making it an enjoyable experience for the whole family. The casual cafe feel was perfect for an after school/ early dinner treat, however moving into the evening, the lights were dimmed and the atmosphere transformed the typical romantic, rustic charm of all good Italian restaurants. I would recommend this treasure of a place for anyone who knows and loves good italian food.

You have to admire a slick shop that can feed the multitudes efficiently on a Bank Holiday Monday. Ciao Baby Cucina is, despite the name, almost a grown-up restaurant. They may even, perhaps, be cooking as much food as they assemble. There was reassuringly someone I took to be a "man-in-charge" (wearing a louder shirt than anyone else without being teased by the waiters). Service was prompt and proficient. The concept and decor was like Carluccios with wood (rather than formica) and larger portions. Unfortunately, the larger portions on our lunch table each included excess doses of salt. Pizza dough was too salty. Lasagne was too salty. Seafood risotto was too salty (and also very high on the chilli-ometer but without any red flag in the menu). The side dishes fared better. Green beans with onions and garlic were under-cooked, but not over-seasoned. Spinach was spot on. Difficult to go wrong with wilted spinach, but I was grateful nonetheless for the small mercy. This place is a whisker away from being an unexpectedly solid choice despite a shopping centre setting. All they need is someone in the kitchen who samples some of the food from time to time and hates marmite. 
Just had lunch there today and it was great. Our Italian waiter Paolo I think was very friendly and gave good explanations of everything (and even complemented me on my pronunciation !). The bruscetta to start was so very fresh. It was followed by a beautifully cooked seabream al forno. The waiter brought over a kind of cake, which when I received it on my plate with ice-cream turned out to be the Italian equivalent of bread and butter pudding - and it was delicious. I would definitely return. 
After a long day’s shopping in Westfield, I walked in to Ciao Baby Cucina and the first thing I noticed is that the decor is modern but unobtrusive, designed for comfort with strategic contrasts of classic Italian charm. When I looked at their menu I saw that it comprises a fabulous choice to suit every taste bud from as little as £6.50. I could choose from a variety of antipasti such as the antipasto misto - a fabulous spread of salami, ham, wood-roasted tomatoes and peppers - followed by freshly cooked pasta and pizza, meat and fish dishes including vitello alla campagnola (crumbed veal layered with chopped spinach and mozzarella, topped with pomodoro and baked in the stone oven), or a classic bistecca alla Florentina - a 1.2kg T-bone char grilled beef steak drizzled with fresh lemon, rosemary and sea salt. The service is efficient, friendly and knowledgeable, the atmosphere relaxed and informal. Ciao Baby is an experience everyone should encounter when visiting the Westfield London Shopping Centre in white City. I was told by the manager that this is the second restaurant that entrepreneur Theo Holiasmenos has opened in the UK. Both follow the same simple concept, offering freshly prepared authentic Italian cuisine in a contemporary, relaxed setting. Ciao Baby Cucina combines deft culinary skills from its experienced chefs together with the freshest ingredients, all hand-cooked in the cucina (kitchen), to make the most delectable savoury and sweet dishes, including Italian breads, pasta, cheeses, gorgeous pastries, cakes and ice creams. To enjoy at home, I bought a little taste of the Ciao Baby Cucina Italian experience. From the irresistible delicatessen table I purchased my own piece of rustic charm from a selection that includes home-baked focaccia breads filled with caramelised onions, sun-fried tomatoes, garlic and herbs, and home-pickled Italian olives in rosemary and garlic flavorings. Stylish Italian dining mixed with a fabulous relaxed atmosphere; Ciao Baby Cucina is an obvious choice whatever the occasion. I will certainly return.

We've come to Cristini's quite a few times since 2007 (often Valentines Day and some meals with family and friends), and have always been impressed by the warm welcome, atmospheric buzz and cosiness, without being claustrophobic. The artwork changes often, but the warm welcome of the staff always makes me feel like I'm coming home.
We asked for olives and garlic bread on arrival. The latter arrived in the form of a light and well-spun pizza dough, just how I like it, with a crisp, bubbled rim and softer centre. Normally this quantity between two would be too much before the starter, but it was so thin as to almost dissolve and was not splattered with butter and cheap dried herbs as is often the way. I selected the pure Cabernet Sauvignon for a palate challenge. I'm embarrassed to say I've forgotten what it was, but the separation between the soft start and loooong finish was huge, a real surprise. The wine engaged us all the way through the meal, without dominating any of the more subtle flavours we encountered. I thought it was pretty good for the price (£23). The food is as excellent as I have eaten as far as Italian food is concerned, each dish prepared with care, and advice given warmly without condescension. My carpaccio of beef was finely sliced with a good portion size, and, for a dish which can so often look two dimensional, stood off the plate with a delightful pile of piquant rocket, delicately sprinked with a light mustard dressing. Clare's open ravioli with lobster bisque was a delight - sea-fresh, but possibly a little too salty (always nagging people for a bite of theirs). I'm in doubt as to whether there was quite enough lobster to justify a £14.50 price, but it was wholesome and flavourful. My spinach garganelli were al dente and well-filled, scattered with soft grilled chicken breast, requiring only a little pepper to bring it out of itself. Portions were very acceptable in size. We shared dessert as I was full. This slightly cheeky request met with no concern whatsoever. The tiramisu, served in a tall glass, was more than large enough for two but was an excellent way to round off the meal, not being heavy or too rich, with definite variation in the layers. Before we left, Mr Cristini poured us each a shot of Limoncello which whilst clashing like mad with the wine was really refreshing, and not something I would have thought to order. The bill was about £85 inclusive of service and £23 for the wine. We felt that was fine for a treat. We'd like to keep the place to ourselves, really, but I thought I'd do them the justice of a fair review and wish them well. Give it a try. What a great way to spend Valentine's evening!

For a business dinner we dined at Incanto in Harrow on the Hill a modern, airy Italian restaurant on the High Street. The food was simply outstanding and beyond that which I have received in more well know, starred restaurants in town. I started with hand dived Scottish scallops, crab and squid ink tortellini with an anise foam. The scallops were generous in their size and beautifully cooked. This was followed by venison cooked three ways with beetroot and balsamic puree, scotchegg and a celeriac and apple galette. Again superb presentation and attention to detail shown in the combinations of the venison. The quails egg on the side was a particular favourite, though my colleagues from France couldn't quite get their head round the concept! Finally a selection of cheeses from the in house delicatessen was accompanied by a small serving of local honey. A very nice selection and each served at just the right temperature. The service was very attentive and precise without being too formal for what is a relaxed dining experience. I'd highly recommend this restaurant. 
I sneaked a peek at the reviews on this site before going the other night and was surprised to find that more hadn't been written up on Incanto. The food isn't just good but outstanding. Their passion for good quality ingredients shows up in every well crafted dish and it's clear if you talk to any of the waiting staff that the pride in their food extends to them too. As a vegetarian, I'm used to menus with a few token dishes added on as an afterthought and have eaten more cheap goat's cheese on wilted salad than I would care to count. No such thing here. The buffalo mozzarella starter was so simple but heavenly. The oozing creaminess of the cheese perfectly complimented the fresh tomatoes and a smooth basil ice cream. I was wondering how the main course could match up when I was delivered a cappaliti (spelling?) pasta filled with a unlikely sounding but delicious concoction of cavalo nero and dandelion flowers with broad bean and truffles. My friends reassured me that their wild sea bass and lamb shoulder were every bit as good as mine. The prices are not cheap but for the quality of ingredients actually amazingly good value. Well worth the trip or in my case many repeat trips. Thank you!

It is not often that I feel the need to write a glowing report on a restaurant. However David Taylor and his fabulous chefs along with the delightful team at ‘Incanto’ do deserve a huge applause for their continued success of the Italian restaurant on Harrow on the Hill. From the very moment I started planning my 40th birthday party this summer, David Taylor ticked all the boxes, with listening to my wishes and soothing my worries. David managed to take away all the stresses and anxieties that I would normally feel in planning the perfect al fresco party. A level of intimacy was created in having my 40th party at ‘Incanto’, following a champagne drinks reception in my rose garden near the restaurant. After creating a summer menu chosen with the freshest seasonal produce available, my friends had plenty to smile about on the night with the exquisite choice of fresh Italian food. The evening started perfectly with canapés, breads and fine wines which flowed in abundance all evening. I enjoyed myself knowing my brand new kitchen was not going to be filled with empty dishes and glasses at the end of the night. I did not have to lift a finger all night, leaving me feeling further refreshed at the end of the party. ‘Incanto’ attended all of our needs even with the last minute party plans and printing of party games. The staff were impeccable in manner and worked to the highest standards we know in the industry. The personal touch was felt all evening from everyone. A sparkle of atmosphere, a professional service, and most importantly the finest food was enjoyed by all and with no worry about cost. The quality and value of the food at ‘Incanto’ is a true gem, and well deserves to be on the top of a list of fine Italian dining restaurants in London. This restaurant really cares about you the customer and delivers the highest standards of food at all times. We look forward to planning more parties in the years to come at ‘Incanto’. A huge thank you to the highly recommended Incanto Team.

The overall service was not that good as we felt throughout the staff were waiting for us to vacate our table so that they could get the next customers in. for all this we paid £85.20 which broken down I believe should have been closer to £70.00 including service charge.
I called in advance to book a table for 14 people at a quiet time (5.45pm-7pm). I was told this was ok. The evening started off on a sour note, as the managers approached us and started to severely tell me off for asking if I could pay for the drinks seperately. From that moment on, even though they were apparently 'very busy upstairs' the managers hovered around our table, making us feel extremely unwanted and uncomfortable. The food was amazing though, and the waiters were fine, it was just the fowl attitude of the managers that means I will NEVER be setting foot in that place again. They even tried to charge me service charge after treating us so badly! They said 'you have to pay it in a place like this, this isn't Nandos' - I wish I HAD gone to Nandos after all! In the end the manager called me 'offensive' for refusing to pay the service charge. So if you want to go for a pre-theatre dinner I don't suggest this one! Try queuing at Prezzo or something.
What a lovely little place. Me and the little woman were very impressed. The couple who run the place are an institution by themselves and they far from seeming miserable where in fact, efficent and brisk. Hurrah for people who do their job properly. great meal and pretty cheap. We will be coming back soon. 
Suspect half the trouble with reviews of this restaurant is that the more you go there the more you know what to order. The fish is always excellent, as are the home-made pasta dishes and the calf's liver - your choice of cooking time and method. I have never in 20-odd years of going here had an unripe melon with my ham when I order this as a starter, and on the whole the salads and side dishes are good - but again knowing what to order is key. The wine list is a joy to read, and the wines very drinkable to excellent. The menu is pretty static but the 'specials' make it endlessly changing with the seasons. I dread the time when the couple who run this wonderful restaurant retire. 
I went for another memorable dinner on the 12th September. Fantastic food and great value wines, Alessandro (owner) was on great form. Suggest the reviewer who rates the "Head waiter - old guy" needs to remember this is the owner of over 30 years who to regular customers is courteous and will offer off the menu wines which he has an interesting variety. If the reviewer didn't want to pay 10% service then they remove it from the bill, don't complain as it is discretionary and can be ultimately removed. I ate at this restaurant last night and thought the food was fantastic. I had the raviola and it was delicious. I could taste the fresh basil in it. I didn't find the portion size too small. In fact I thought it was just right. I hate being served huge portions of food in a restaurant, which tends to put me off the food. I thought it was very reasonably priced as well for the quality of food and the extremely pleasant atmosphere (especially for Central London).and nice decor I loved the opera music they played as background music. Really added to the ambience. As far as the 10 percent added on, I prefer that restaurants do that as I feel uncomfortable with tipping. Most restaurants that add on a tip seem to add on at least 12 percent and sometimes 15 percent. If you don't think you got good service you don't have to pay the tip. I found the service quite efficient although I must admit our waiter seemed a bit miserable. Maybe he had had a bad day. In spite of that he gave good service. I can't stand having the waiter or server acting as though he or she is my new best friend, telling me his/her name and hovering around our table all night. The older gentleman came over to our table and was very friendly without being obtrusive. I wanted to order two starters but he suggested I just have one, which turned out to be just enough food. Two starters would have filled me up. Personally, I very much enjoyed eating there and have recommended it to several of my wifes. I will certainly go back there again even though it means a long commute for me on the underground. Lucky locals who can go there all the time! Keep up the good work and the great food. 
We went to Locale for a late lunch at the weekend. The food was very good; it was simple but very tasty, 'honest', food. What was very disappointing however was the service. When my friend asked whether it was possible to have a larger serving of the Insalata Caprese, she was asked: 'You mean double?' When my friend hesitated and I asked whether it wasn't possible for her to have her Caprese at the size of a main course, the waitress turned to me and said: 'Yes, but I will charge her double' (literally). Given that attitude I am not sure I would go back; although that's a pity, as otherwise it seems like the perfect place for a quick, decent, warm lunch in the centre of London.

Big mistake.
Summary: Service - completely overstretched. I'm sure the girls serving are well intentioned, but they are simply too few in number (typical chain problem) and hence you're kept waiting for long stretches, even before you've sat down. Food - Poor. I ordered a sirloin steak (it WAS Steak Mondays...) and it was dry and tough. No excuse for it. ANYONE can cook a steak. The mashed potatoes were extremely salty, and the green beans came in two markedly different shades - half were fresh, and half were old. Ambience - most of the clientele seem to be tourists hoovered up from South Bank. Including lots of families, with shrieking bawling kids. Great if that's your thing, not if it's not. In conclusion, I'll never go again. And it's literally a 15 second walk from my front door.

New York is often referred to as the home of world's greatest chefs. Most of the expensive New York City restaurants are booked the majority of the year and you typically need a rfeservation a month or two in advance to dine there. These New York City Restaurants include Masa, Alain Ducasse at the Essex House Restaurant, Kuruma Zushi, Per Se, daniel restaurant New York City, Le Bernardin, Sugiyama, MEGU, Jean Georges and Atelier. Masa, a Japanese restaurant in Time Warner Center, is a famous New York City Restaurant that has only 26 seats. Per Se is another New York City restaurant where diners can enjoy Thomas Keller's Napa Valley cuisine.

New York City Sea Food Restaurants
New York City Restaurant Le Bernardin serves the best seafood. The menu here has categories on their menu such as "Almost Raw", "Barely Touched" and "Lightly Cooked". Customers dining in this New York City restaurant enjoy the best aspects of seafood.

Japanese Restaurants in New York City/ Sushi Restaurant New York City

If you want to experience some of the finest Japanese dining, the MEGU is one of the best New York City restaurants that imports its ingredients for added authenticity. The menu here is broken up into 11 different groupings.

The New York City Restaurant Atelier has a creative and award-winning menu. The unique cuisine of Atelier has been inspired by the chef's home in the south of France.

Kuruma Zushi is a New York City Restaurant that flies its fish all the way from Japan. It makes the Sushi served here world-class, the restaurant all the more unique, and diners are impressed.

Italian restaurants New York City
There are many good Italian restaurants in New York City. Serafina is one of the best Italian restaurants in New York City. Grilled Calamari, tuna steak, and brick oven pizza are some dishes they offer. You can refer to a New York Restaurant City Guide for choosing the best New York City restaurants for each type of cuisine; French, Japanese, Italian etc.

Carmines restaurant New York City is an award-winning restaurant and the first choice of many New Yorkers. The menu of this New York City restaurant includes Italian and continental cuisine. I don't know if it's controversial, but it's a bit like asking for the best French restaurant in the city, and then saying entrees less than $30.

What you are really asking for is best medium-priced Italian, which is a lot different than best Italian.

By artfuldestruct on Oct 05, 2007 09:29AM

#

I went to NYC for the first time a week ago and went to Little Italy. I had the best meal ever at Il Palazzo (bowl of pasta in white sauce, prosciutto, mushrooms). Wow! I had a great seat by the window and the service was excellent! Italian music played in the background and the glass of wine was the best I've ever had.

Foodwise, Crispo is in my opinion the best overall. I have never spent more than $120 for 2 people for 2 courses and a bottle of wine. The food is always fresh, interesting and delicious, and the menu is quite varied. I go there very often and never get bored with the menu. The veal breast parmesan is a wonderful variation on a (usually boring or awful) classic. Such simple things as mozzarella with roasted peppers and sausage-stuffed sage leaves rise to new heights here.

In the higher end category, I consider Babbo to be the most pleasant overall dining experience. The food is innovative without straying too much from "true Italian". And it is really not so expensive for what you get, including a well-chosen selection of moderately priced wines.

By rrems on Oct 25, 2007 09:07AM

#

Of course the answer to this questions is subjective, but there are a lot of BAD suggestions in this thread.

When I want a good and authentic Italian meal, I go to one of these places for the following reasons:

1. Aurora SoHo. The food is outstanding and sitting at the bar gets you fresh air from the open storefront doors and some solid people watching.
2. Pepolino. The owners are from one of my favorite restaurants in Florence: Cibreo. Their Italian food might be the best I've had in the States. Most of the staff is off-the-boat Florentine and they know their stuff. Outdoor tables here too, 2 interior dining rooms.
3. Bar Pitti. The food is simple, authentic and priced right. The outdoor tables in front are such a scene, you wonder why they bother making such good food. They could probably make money serving less.
4. Morandi. The food is better now than it's ever been, it's a beautiful space and the menu is varied and well-planned. There is little issue here with authenticity at all and their wines by the glass are impressive.
5. Arturo's. Old-school, red-sauce, pizza joint with good Italian-American dishes prepared with fresh ingredients and offered inexpensively. Not gourmet, or even authentic "Italian", but never a bad meal here. The live jazz music adds unparalleled old Village charm.

Other honorable mentions: Crispo, Lavagna, Scarpetta,

babbo, picola venezia, manducattis

Times Square is a popular destination for visitors to New York City, but the area is plagued with mediocre chain restaurants. Skip the tourist traps and have a great meal at one of these recommended Times Square restaurants.

Times Square Neighborhood Guide | Times Square Map | Pre-Theater Restaurants
1. Becco
People flock to Becco, either because of co-owner Lidia Bastianich (of PBS) or to enjoy the all you can eat pasta special, featuring antipasto or salad and three pastas nightly. Although you're unlikely to spot Lidia, you won't leave hungry.

    * Address: 355 West 46th St (8th Ave)
    * Phone: 212-397-7597
    * Cuisine: Italian
    * Hours: Mon-Fri: 12-2:25 pm; 5-10:30 pm; Sat: 4:30-10:30 pm; Sun: 5-10 pm
    * Price Range: pasta special: lunch $16.95, dinner $21.95; a la carte: approx $40
    * Good for Kids/Groups? Yes
2. John's Pizzeria
Housed in a deconsecrated church, John's Pizzeria is renowned for its coal oven pizza. The Times Square outpost of the famed Greenwich Village original serves up the best pizza in the neighborhood and solid Italian sandwiches and entrees. (No pizza by the slice.)

    * Address: 260 West 44th St (7th/8th Aves)
    * Phone: 212-582-8065
    * Cuisine: Pizza/Italian
    * Hours: 11:30 am - 11:30 pm
    * Price Range: entrees/sandwiches $8-15; pizza $10-16
    * Good for Kids/Groups? Yes (special packages available for groups)
3. Churrascaria Platforma
Brazillian rodizio at Churrascaria Platforma is a great choice for those with big appetites and large groups, seeking a celebratory atmosphere. The prix-fixe includes the endless grilled meats and the extensive salad bar, but not dessert. Diners use a double-sided green/red chip to indicate when they want more meat served.

    * Address: 316 West 49th Street (8th/9th Aves)
    * Telephone: 212-245-0505
    * Cuisine: Brazillian
    * Hours: 12 pm - 12 am
    * Price Range: lunch $30.95, dinner $46.95
    * Good for Kids/Groups? Yes
4. Wu Liang Ye
Wu Liang Ye is regarded among Manhattan's best Sichuan restaurants. Sichuan dumplings, Kung Pao chicken and cold sesame noodles are some of the most popular dishes. Be warned -- Sichuan dishes tend to be hot -- if you prefer your food less spicy, be sure to let the waiter know.

    * Address: 36 West 48th St (5th/6th Aves)
    * Telephone: 212-398-2308
    * Cuisine: Chinese/Sichuan
    * Hours: 12 pm - 9:30 pm
    * Price Range: lunch special $6.95; entrees $8-20 (seafood and specialty items at top of range)
    * Good for Groups? Yes
5. Edison Cafe
Located in the Edison Hotel, the Edison Cafe serves up affordable food all day long, including pancakes, matzo ball soup, and deli sandwiches. Edison Cafe is a reliable standby and popular with those who work in the neighborhood -- meaning you might just spot a theater big-wig or star dining there.

    * Address: 228 West 47th St (Broadway and 8th Ave)
    * Telephone: 212-840-5000
    * Cuisine: American/Delicatessen
    * Hours: Mon - Sat: 6 am - 9:30 pm; Sun: 6 am - 7:30 pm
    * Price Range: $5-10
6. Ruby Foos
This fun, funky Asian fusion restaurant has a great atmosphere and features creative takes on dim sum, sushi, and Thai dishes, designed for sharing. The children's menu has familiar items like hot dogs and grilled cheese. Reservations are recommended, though after 8, tables are easier to come by.

    * Address: 1626 Broadway (49th St.)
    * Telephone: 212-489-5600
    * Cuisine: Asian Fusion
    * Hours: 11:30 a.m. - midnight (11 p.m. Sunday - Wednesday)
    * Price Range: $6-30
    * Good for Kids/Groups? Yes

7. Virgil's
Surprisingly, Virgil's offers some of New York City's best barbecue, including Memphis ribs and Carolina Pulled Pork. Portions are generous and they have a full bar with signature drinks. Reservations are recommended -- allow plenty of time if you're going to a show afterward, as service can be slow.

    * Address: 152 West 44th Street (Bdwy/6th Ave)
    * Telephone: 212-921-9494
    * Cuisine: Southern/BBQ
    * Hours: 11:30 AM - Midnight (11 p.m. on Sun/Mon)
    * Price Range: $8-22 for entrees
    * Good for Kids/Groups? Yes

8. Kodama
Affordable sushi served in a simply decorated environment is the reason to check out Kodama. Their lunch specials are a good deal, and they are known for serving solid maki, including a Canadian roll featuring salmon, and spicy greens.

    * Address: 301 West 45th St. (8th Ave)
    * Telephone: 212-582-8065
    * Cuisine: Japanese/Sushi
    * Hours: Mon-Fri: 12 - 2:25 pm; 5 - 10:30 pm; Sat: 4:30 -10:30 pm; Sun: 5 - 10 pm
    * Price Range: lunch $8-15; dinner $10-25
agat Survey, publisher of the top New York restaurant and nightlife directories, recently released their 2011 guide to New York City restaurants. The new Zagat guide is based on the opinions of more than 40,000 locals and covers a record 2,115 restaurants. The typical restaurant in the survey was visited by five to six Zagat surveyors every day of the year.

The 2011 Zagat survey shows that New Yorkers are still dining out less and making more frugal choices. The average cost of a meal out in New York City actually declined slightly since last year to $41.76, the first decrease in that number since 2002.

The good news is that Zagat surveyors have noted improvements in hospitality and service and shorter wait times for tables. After all, New Yorkers aren't about to give up eating, drinking, and being merry altogether. 
And the big Zagat winners are....
The top-rated restaurants for 2011 include plenty of old favorites and some hot newcomers.

    * Best Newcomer: Maialino in the Gramercy Park Hotel was rated the best new restaurant in New York City.


    * Best Food: Eric Ripert's Le Bernardin wins the Best Food title again for 2011.


    * Best Service: Thomas Keller's Per Se at Time Warner Center earned top honors for service for the second year running.

We were in the City this past weekend - on the suggestion of some of the 'local' experts we tried Le Zie, 7th Avenue b'twn 20th and 21st.

It is far superior than what you will find in Little Italy, the food is excellent, service very cordial and the prices are very reasonable (for NYC).

2. Re: Good Italian Restaurant In Midtown Manhattan
Jan 18, 2007, 2:02 PM
Destination Expert   What's this?
for New York City

Little Italy is no longer a destination for outstanding Italian food. (I'm not sure it ever was). Italian is probably the most popular type of restaurant in Manhattan--beyond what is called "American." You will find all kinds of Italian (northern/tuscan, southern/red sauce, piedmontese etc.) in all neighborhoods at all price points in all sizes, shapes and forms

If by midtown you mean near the theater district, Vice Versa is very good and has some good value prix fixe menus. If you want something more unusual/upscale, L'Impero is wonderful.

If you're more specific about the type of food/place/location you want, we can make some more recos. I haven't been to Le Zie (which is just south of midtown) so can't compare it but I'd trust the reco if the menu looks good to you. Have you checked menupages.com?
5. Re: Good Italian Restaurant In Midtown Manhattan
Jan 18, 2007, 3:06 PM

Whether or not you`re a fan of Lidia Bastianich`s PBS cooking show, "Lidia`s Italian-American Kitchen," her theatre distict restaurant, Becco, is always excellent and I never miss an opportunity to dine there on my frequent visits to NYC. It`s located on restaurant row at 355 W. 46th Street between 8th and 9th Avenues. Phone is 212-397-7957. This is a casually elegant place with lots of charm, outstanding, friendly service and authentic, simple, hearty Italian fare. Prices are surprisingly reasonable. Becco is well known for it`s justifiably popular SINFONIA di PASTA. This is a prix fixe for $16.95 at lunch and $21.95 for dinner. It includes wonderful breads, either a caesar salad or an excellent antipasto misto consisiting of marinated grilled vegetables and seafood (the better option.) The servers then arrive with tableside service from saute pans, of the 3 pastas of the day with unlimited servings. This is always stellar and a great value, although the entire menu is not to be overlooked. The in house made dessert sampler for 2 ($11.00) is perhaps New York`s best dessert value too and there is an extensive list of Italian wines for $25 a bottle. Becco is always exremely busy during pretheatre dining hours so reservations are highly recommended, or go during theatre perfomance times or post theatre when things are a bit quieter, but it`s always a memorable dining experience here. Check out the Tripadvisor reviews.

7. Re: Good Italian Restaurant In Midtown Manhattan
Jan 18, 2007, 4:28 PM

Avoid the touristy overpriced and attitude laden theatre district delis, The Carnegie and The Stage on 7th Avenue. If you want the real New York Jewish Deli experience you`ll have to travel to Katz`s Delicatessn at 205 E. Houston St. at Ludlow St. 212-254-2246. This is the real deal and it`s been around since 1888. This is great traditional deli food at reasonable prices and they won`t charge you extra for sharing one of their great sandwiches with someone else like they do at those other places.
8. Re: Good Italian Restaurant In Midtown Manhattan
Jan 18, 2007, 4:40 PM
Destination Expert   What's this?
for New York City

Well the pastrami experts (not me) would differ with quindad and say run don't walk to the Carnegie deli. If you like thin cut pastrami, that's the place to go. Katz's is good but cut thicker. Ben's Kosher deli may be closer to your hotel and is good.

Just south of Times Square generally means the garment center area. One of the best restaurants there is Keen's Steakhouse if you like meat (not just steak, they're also famous for their mutton chop). If you eat in the bar/pub area off the pub menu it's cheaper.

Basilica and Roberto Passon are 2 places on 9th ave in the 40's that are well regarded italians. Basilica is just a small, neighborhood place with good prices. (R Passon is too, but nicer).

People swoon over Mario Batali's restaurants. The one closest to you would be Esca.
